title: Fast and Flexible Selection with a Single Switch
segmentation: Introduction This is joint work with David Mackay at the University of Cambridge.
And basically, I'll be presenting a single switch selection method that I developed with David.

So just a little background by single Switch I mean that the input to our method is a series of times, so these times might have been generated by clicking a button by blinking an really by sort of any individual muscle movement, and in the context of this mini symposium, we're thinking obviously of individuals who, because of some disability, have extremely limited range of movement.
So sort of almost completely locked in syndrome.

And something I'm just going to notice that this is a more restrictive case than, say, Morse code, which with which most people are familiar where we have not only the activation times of the switches, but in fact the duration, and that may be difficult for some people to sort of do accurately, so we're just interested in the activation Times Now, even in this restricted case there are already some communication aids, so the most common is scanning where you have sort of a variety of options they don't have to be just letters like here.
They could be words, functions, anything.

Arranged in a grid format and the way that you select something in that grid, is there a rose are highlighted successively in the grid at some time delay and you blink or click your button or whatever.
When it gets to the row with the option that you want, and then the same thing happens with the columns, the columns are highlighted successively at some time delay and you.
Click your switch again and you've selected, you know, say R. Now one button Dasher is a more recent.
Recent way of communicating with.

Just a single switch input and the idea of 1 button Dasher is similar to Dasher if you're at all familiar with that method where you sort of have all possible strings of words arranged alphabetically and you're sort of zooming in on the one that you want and.
The one button is used to adjust the zooming and I won't go into too much detail about that except to say that in both of these communication methods one button Dasher and scanning.
We have various restrictions, so one button dash or you have to have something that's arranged alphabetically.
You're basically interested in creating words, and in scanning it's not necessarily the same.

You can have functions, you can have various other things you are selecting, but things are still arranged in a grid and the way that we usually use our computers speaking as somebody who's able and using a regular computer.

Is that we have a GUI and for your operating system you're just going to click on some icon on your desktop and the way that you surf the web is you're just going to click on some link and you're just going to be clicking at various points on your GUI, and that's the idea behind our method.
Nauman is that you really can't select anything on your computer screen.
It doesn't have to be arranged in a very specific way.
And I'm just going to demo that to show you what exactly does I mean by by anything?
'cause that's a pretty broad statement.
So while it's loading, we have some quotes from nominee users in a study that I'm going to describe later.
But basically they found it fun.
It looks weird when it first comes up, so I'm going to warn you about that.
But it's actually easy.
So here's the non keyboard good.
It all appears on screen.
So there's a lot going on here, and I'm going to break it down first.
We have each of these rectangles that includes some letter, so this is just a writing application.

The nominee selection method is the clocks, and I'll get to that in a moment, but for our reading application we have a letter in each of these blocks, and then there's some word completions so things that begin with that letter.
Now in general, when you've written something, it will begin with what you've written so far.
Then the letter in the block, and then some other stuff that completes the word.
You also have some special characters, so we have a_for space.
For just punctuation, delete gets rid of the last character and what's the text box in whatever is in the text box, and undo undoes everything else.
So let's get to the heart of the matter here, what what do I do to actually select something in this interface?
So let's all look at a, which is in the upper left hand corner, and you'll notice that there's this Clock right next to it, and that is the selection mechanism.
What I'm going to do in order to select a is click as close as possible to noon.
And here's the important part.
I don't have to be perfect, and I'm not going to be non is going to take care of that.
So as my single switch I have the space bar of this computer and again it could be anything but so just bear with me.
This is this is moving this Clock and I'm just going to click at noon and I just did that.
So I'm going to do it again, click.
Click an A has been selected and you know that happened because everything lit up green A in particular little darker green and down in the text box.
We have a little a appearing now.
Normally there would be some sort of auditory feedback too, but I don't have that for technical reasons.
Now let's say I want to write the word about.
I'm going to go to the next door and I see that about actually appears as a word completion, so I don't have to find the B and write.
The BI can actually write about just just as it stands.
So all I do is again I select things in exactly the same way I find the word about.
I go to the little Clock that's right next to it and I'm going to click when that Clock is at noon.
So I'm looking at that Clock.
And I click and actually, you know, maybe I'm bored with the system right now and I'm going to look over this way or do something else, or read a paper I can come back whenever I feel like it.
All that matters is where I click when the Clock is spinning.
It doesn't matter how much time I take off to do whatever I feel like.
So I've come back and I'm still going for about.
And I click and I click.
And about is selected and now I have that word and I can keep writing things in the same way.
So you see that the desktop is sort of gone back to the original way that it was.
I can get those word completions.
I can get those letters and everything else.
So I'm going to mention a few more things about this.
I will mention right now that you can download this for free online.
I'm going to give you a URL at the end, so I would hope that you would experiment with with it on your own.
There's also a drawing application that we have, but so for this a few more points you can change the Clock rotation speed at the top.
If this is too fast you can make it slower, etc.
And there are two Clock colors, so you'll notice that there is yellow and white.

And what that's about is I'm going to get into our calculation posterior probabilities, but basically yellow means it's a higher posterior probability of that Clock or higher prior when you haven't clicked yet, and white means it's a lower posterior probability.
So this is an indicator to the user.
Are you doing the right thing?

So as you're clicking towards the selection, you should see that your Clock is staying yellow and everything else is becoming white, and if that's not the case, maybe you need to click a little bit more accurately this time.
So that's basically nominant in nutshell.
And I'll just.
Get back to talking about how Nomin actually works.
So like I like I hinted at in the Nomin demo, it's basically just posterior inference at each round and by around I mean a series of clicks towards a selection.
So around begins at the very beginning, or when you've already made a selection and you're ready to make another one.
So to do posterior inference, we need a prior and likelihood.

Now the prior is it's fully something that you can set according to your application in Nam and there's no restriction on the prior, but our nominee keyboard which I just showed you is an example of an online application and our prior we chose to have preset priors on these special characters and functions like delete and undo that you saw and then chose frequencies from the British National Corpus because again this was taking place in the United Kingdom and use Laplace smoothing to get actual probabilities from that.
For the alphabetic characters in Word completions.
Now this is fixed in the current nominal implementation.
Whenever I get to that first sort of like word set for example, you're always going to see the same probabilities.

In general, you would want that to change as you use Nauman overtime, it's going to choose, you know it's going to see that I use the word Tamera lot and make that more probable, and that's something you can absolutely do with Nam and we just didn't, because the most anybody ever used it in our user try.
With one hour so.
That's not as important now.
Likelihood was that actually, that histogram thing that you saw onaman towards the beginning.
You might have been wondering what was that?
That's actually a fully nonparametric estimate of what your Click to distribution from 6:00 AM to 6:00 PM is.
So it starts out with an initial estimate and all that you really saw while I was using it was that initial estimate because I didn't use it for very long at all.
But it's updated with a modified person window estimator based on your user clicks as you use it.
So you can start off immediately, but overtime it will adapt to you.
So if you're very precise as I am after I use it for awhile, it's going to let me choose things and Nauman with just one or two clicks.
An on the other hand, if you're very imprecise, it gives you the time to make a selection that you need so that you're not always undoing.

Now this actually works on a delay, so that if you were to undo something, you're implicitly saying, oh, I don't want those clicks to actually count for something so we don't use those clicks in our actual estimate of your distribution, and it's damped because you're probably going.

It's possible that you're going to change your use of Nauman overtime, you know if you just started it, maybe you're not that accurate with how you click, but later on you might become more accurate and we wanted to be able to adapt to that, not just be set in stone from the beginning.
So once we have this prior in a likelihood we.
And calculate the posterior probability of each of the clocks wherever they are.
And another nice thing about nominees that a parameter of the model is the cutoff.
So once we have this posterior probability, we can order the clocks and say what's the most likely Clock.
And the way that the selection is actually made an ominous, not a fixed number of rounds or anything like in scanning.
It's when you're the posterior probability of the highest probability Clock reaches a threshold, and you can set that threshold.
So if you're just typing and you want to be very fast, you can set it sort of low.

You know you don't really mind on doing, and if you have a very secure action like you want to delete a file or shut down your computer and just get rid of everything you've been working on, you want that to be very secure and in some sense you know your computer is approximating this when you're on a Unix station and it says.
Yes no.
Really want to delete this file and this is sort of a really sort of beige and motivated way of actually doing that.
So finally, does this actually work and people actually use this?

People who haven't been using in designing it like I have, so we actually recruited 16 able participants from the University of Cambridge who had no previous experience with any single switch interface, and in particular not with scanning, which was the grid like interface that I described at the beginning or with Nauman because it's very new.
And they were paying £10 for each of one hour for each of two one hour sessions.
So in one session we gave them a variety of prompts from a standard set of prompts and we told them to write those prompts with one of the interfaces.

Now that session was divided into 14414 minutes sections and in the last section we said we're going to time you were going to say what is your reading speed and if you are writing speed is in the top half of writing speeds for that particular interface will give you a 5 pound bonus, so you don't have to be super fast, but you kind of want to be on your ball and pay attention.
And the result was that actually novices wrote 35% faster with nominal and with no difference in their error rate when they did that.
Also, in this graph we have clicks per character on the side.
And again, these are on the 414 minute blocks that I described.

An clicks per character is interesting because if you are in fact a disabled user using this system, it might be that it takes you effort to actually make those clicks to make that single switch selection.
And so we want to minimize that.
So it's nice to see that nominee actually doesn't take a lot more clicks than the opposing interface, and in fact what we have here is also experienced user data.
So that's me.
After using each of these both, both the grid and Nauman for over 10 hours, and I think that all you can really get from that is actually.
It's possible to get to do quite a bit better with Nauman and quite a bit better with clicks per character.
An writing speed after some time after using these interfaces.
And another interesting thing, an important thing when we're thinking about not only the disabled community, but anybody who's using this is isn't enjoyable.
Is it something that you could see yourself using for any sort of long term use?
And so we also administered questionnaires to the participants after using both nominant scanning.
And one thing we noticed was that each participant wrote that they enjoyed using them, and at least as much as the scanning software.
And on average they enjoyed using it more.
And again, that's no small result.
So finally, there are definitely a lot of things that we want to be changing.
Next I've talked a lot about able users using this.
It's very new software.
I mean, we've just developed it.
But we're definitely interested in seeing you know what about individuals who really do have a limited range of communication.
How do they feel about this software?
Is it easier for them to use them scanning?
Is it more fun?
Is it something that they would like to use?
And again, because this is very new, there remain a lot of theoretical questions.
Is the Clock representation the best sort of continuous periodic representation that we could have?
Is there something it's been suggested?
Maybe a bouncing ball or some sort of moving stick or something that would be either easier for people to use, or in fact let them be faster at using this interface.
Also, we set a lot of parameters, sort of what seemed reasonable.
Maybe if those parameters were optimized, people could again make choices faster with Nauman and.
We used heuristics to maximize the information right now, but again, that's something that might be rewarded by some more theoretical research.
An again make make this.
More enjoyable experience.
So finally I'd like to thank everybody who contributed to this project and I'd like to thank all of you for listening.
